text: <extra_id_0> Single-immunoglobulin IL-1 receptor-related <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) protein , also known as <extra_id_0> TIR-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is a member of the TLR / IL-1R family that has been extensively characterised as an inhibitor of <extra_id_0> IL-1R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and TLR signalling , probably through direct interaction with these receptors , <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IRAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 67 ] ( Figure 1 ) .

Given the important role of <extra_id_0> IL-1R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and TLR signalling in the chronic inflammation observed in RA [ 68 ] , a regulatory role for <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA is not unlikely .

<extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has a very restricted expression pattern , being expressed in epithelial cells , monocytes and immature dendritic cells , but not in mature macro-phages [ 69 , 70 ] .
Recently , <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression was shown to inhibit the spontaneous release of inflammatory cytokines by human RA synovial cells .

This inhibitory function of <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was further confirmed in vivo , since <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice developed a more severe disease in zymosan - induced arthritis , as well as collagen - induced arthritis mouse models [ 70 ] .

It will be interesting to compare the expression of <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA patients with its expression in control patients , or to investigate whether the function of <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is compromised in RA patients .
Because of its restricted expression pattern , <extra_id_0> SIGIRR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may also be an interesting therapeutic target in RA .
